title: 104_hr1403
content: The "Ammunition Safety Act of 1995" may be cited as the short title. Dealers of ammunition are addressed in the Act. The "Ammunition Safety Act of 1995" amends various sections of title 18, United States Code, to include regulations on firearms and ammunition. This includes changes to licensing requirements for dealing in ammunition and setting a fee of $10 per year for dealing in non-destructive device ammunition. Additionally, unlawful acts related to firearms and ammunition are also addressed in the Act. The Code is amended to include regulations on firearms and ammunition, such as inserting "or ammunition" after "firearms" and "firearm" in various paragraphs. The Code is amended to include regulations on firearms and ammunition, with penalties increased for violations of section 922(g) for individuals over 18 years old. The Code is amended to include regulations on firearms and ammunition, with penalties increased for violations of section 922(g) for individuals over 18 years old. Section 922(t) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include "or ammunition" after "firearm" each place it appears, with increased penalties for violations. SEC. 3. REGULATION OF ARMOR PIERCING AND NEW TYPES OF DESTRUCTIVE AMMUNITION. The amendment to Section 921(a)(17) of title 18, United States Code, requires the Secretary to establish uniform standards for testing projectiles used in handguns and define 'armor piercing ammunition' based on their ability to pierce armor within a year of enactment. The expenses for this testing will be covered by ammunition manufacturers. The amendment requires the testing and rating of ammunition's destructive capacity, including armor piercing ammunition, with expenses covered by manufacturers. Section 922(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include possession and use restrictions. The amendment adds restrictions on the manufacture, importation, or use of projectiles with lower armor piercing ratings, with testing expenses covered by manufacturers. The amendment imposes limitations on projectiles with lower armor piercing ratings, requiring manufacturers to cover testing expenses.
